channel.title: OpenCounter
channel.description: Helping you start your business in Santa Cruz.

item.title: Welcome
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded:
Please know you are always welcome to visit the Planning Department ⇣ during their open hours: Mon to Thurs 7am-12pm.

x

The Planning Department's public counter is located in room 206 of City Hall, 809 Center Street, Santa Cruz, CA. It's on the second floor in the annex building.

Open Monday - Thursday • 7 am to 12 pm
Closed Fridays.

Staff will be available in the afternoon by phone or appointment only. The office is closed from 12-1 for lunch, 5pm is quitting time.

Contact planningcounter@cityofsantacruz.com Tel: 831-420-5100 • Fax: 831-420-5434

Planning Department 809 Center Street, Room 206 Santa Cruz, California 95060

Here are some more people who can help ⇣.

x

The Central Coast Small Business Development Center (SBDC).

The Santa Cruz Public Library has a reference desk and online guide.

The Office of Economic Development.

Your broker, property manager or landlord.

item.title: The Law
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded:
Starting a business requires some paperwork. Sorry, it’s the law!

The paperwork is dependent on what you do and where you are located.

Every business in Santa Cruz needs a business license and a use permit, even if you are working from home.

item.title: Where do you plan to work?
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded:
If you are working from home, you can apply online for your business license and use permit. Apply here.

If your business is in a space other than your home, it is more complicated. Please continue onward, it's not that bad!

item.title: Zoning - 1
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded:
Zoning basically makes sure a rubber factory can't open next to a preschool.

By clustering types of businesses, we can help preserve neighborhoods and share services.

The first hurdle to starting a business is finding a location that permits your use.

item.title: Use - 2
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded:
A good tip for finding a location that permits your use is to pick a space with a prior use as similar to yours as possible.

If you are opening a restaurant try to go into a space that held a restaurant.

If you are opening a yoga studio try to go into, say, a karate studio.

This will make it more likely that your use will be approved.

If the past use matches your use, the zoning will match and parking will likely not be an issue.

SiteMyBiz is a helpful tool to find available space in Santa Cruz.

item.title: Intensity of use - 5
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded:
A gym has a more "intense use" than a warehouse. This means more parking is needed and means more cars on the road.

If the prior use of your site is similar or less intense ⇣ than what you do, this doesn't affect you. Move along!

x

Here are some businesses listed from light to intense use: Warehouse < Shoe store < Restaurant

More information coming soon.

But, if you need to change a space to a more "intense use" you must pay for the impacts you'll be causing. Please read more about it ⇣.

x

This is a complicated concept. In California, it’s our responsibility to mitigate the impact of changes of use if the “intensity” of use increases. This means accounting for more traffic, parking and people using the space.

It costs a lot to keep the traffic of Santa Cruz flowing.

If your business has a higher traffic need than your space allows it is your responsibility to pay into a fund that helps traffic improvements. This is done by a one time charge called Traffic Impact Fee (TIF). TIF helps pay for things like wider lanes and signalized intersections.

TIF can be $1000 to $200,000. This is why we reccomend picking a location with a similar use to yours.

The fee is based on the number of trips your use switch causes. Here is a tool that helps estimate the fee:

If you love a space with a serious TIF you should talk to The office of Economic Development. They will try to help.

x

item.title: Parking - 6
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded:
A business must provide sufficient parking.

If you don't have enough spaces, your customers will use the street, which will block traffic, or use other businesses' spots, which is not fair.

Your use affects the parking spaces required ⇣. More people buy food than couches, so a super market requires more parking than a furniture store.

x

Here is the table that is used to calculate the number of parking spots needed for space and use.

[table id=2 /]

If the resulting number of parking spots contains a fraction and that fraction is greater than half you must round up and add a full parking space.

x

If you are located downtown ⇣, you don't need to provide parking, but you must pay ⇣ for it.

x

More information coming soon.

Downtown has shared parking with reduced requirements. So if you don't have off street parking, you can pay into a shared fund that runs the City garages and lots.


x

item.title: Building Permits -7
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded:
Painting a wall is fine. Moving a wall needs a building permit.

When making improvements to your space it is important to talk to the Building Department ⇣, even if it is just installing a sign ⇣. The public is going to use your business, and the city's job is to ensure public safety.

x


More information coming soon. Please visit the building department for help.

x


A building permit is needed for most signs. More information coming soon.

If you are doing substantial renovations, you must hire a professional architect or engineer.

item.title: Water - 8
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded:
If you have anything to do with food, or industrial uses you may need to obtain a waste water discharge permit or questionnaire ⇣.

x

Waste water regulation helps the department of Public Works prevent grease and other pollutants from clogging their water treatment facility and the bay. More information and an application can be found here.

This permit is not required of most retail and service uses.

The last thing the city requires of you is a business licence.

item.title: Business Licence -8
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded:
Once you have your use permit and any tenant improvements approved, you'll need a business licence from the Finance department.

Getting a Business license is a breeze.

Business Licenses help the city categorize employers and keep track of its employment base. This is important information that guides city services. Your business License needs to be renewed each year.

It is more of a tax than a license.

item.title: Thanks
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded:
Thanks for reading this guide.

If you are ready to start your business, you can use the form below to receive a personal check list of what you need to do to comply with permitting for your chosen location and business.

[gravityform id="1" name="Request a check list from planning"]

item.title: Home Occupant
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded:
No making whiskey in your basement.

There are a few rules about working from home. You can't advertise your business with a sign. You must not drastically change the residential character of your home.

Home Occupation rules are fully described by 24.10.160 of the municipal code, it is short and should be read!

Fictitious business name & Incorporation are two things you should be aware of related to taxes ⇣.

x

1.If the name of your business does not contain your last name you will need to apply to county for a Fictitious business name (FBN).

For example, if your businees is called "Smith’s Tanning" a FBN is NOT needed, but if it is called "Jamaica Me Tan" a FBN is needed.

2. You don't need to incorporate, but it should be something you think about. A corporate structure can protect private assets. For more information on incorporation talk to an accountant or visit The California Business Portal.

To work from home you need a zoning clearance ⇣ (aka your use permit) which costs $221.00, and a business license ⇣ which costs $145.15 a year plus $4 for each additional employee.

x



More information coming soon.

x

Business Licenses help the city categorize employers and keep track of its employment base. This is important information that guides city services. Your business License needs to be renewed each year.

The $145.15 fee goes toward the general fund that pays for city staff.

APPLY:

[gravityform id="5" name="Home Occupant Application"]

item.title: Map - 3
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded:
You can check a site's zoning and prior use by entering the address here:

Example: 1367 Pacific Avenue

All zones are defined by title 24 of the Municipal code.

  • CBD Central Business District ⇣
  • CBD-E Subdistrict Lower Pacific Ave ⇣
  • CC Community Commercial ⇣
  • CN Neighborhood Commercia ⇣
  • CT Thoroughfare Commercial ⇣
  • PA Professional and Administrative Office ⇣
  • CB Beach Commercial ⇣
  • IG General Industrial ⇣

x

CBD Central Business District

Only found in Downtown Santa Cruz, this zoning allows most retail and food uses. Developed in the aftermath of the Loma Prieta earthquake, this district also includes a shared parking and marketing resources and has lower development impact fees.

Ex. of principally permitted uses include: restaurants, shoes, boutiques, ice cream parlors, cafes and bike shops

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: barber shops, laundries and cleaning establishments, business and technical schools

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Tattoo parlor, Heavy manufacturing, and ground floor professional and administrative uses along Pacific Avenue.

Please read the Municipal Code & the downtown recovery plan

x

CBD-E Subdistrict Lower Pacific Ave

Set up to help bridge the downtown to the beach area, this district encourages mixed uses that include commercial and recreational businesses.

Ex. of principally permitted uses include: art galleries, restaurants, boutiques, cafes and dance studios

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: bars, meeting halls, off street parking facilities, convenience stores.

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: mortuaries, manufacturing

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

x

CC Community Commercial

Primary zoning for most major commercial corridors, this district is set up to permit many different types of uses.

Ex. of principally permitted uses include: Apparel stores, auto supply, restaurants, home furnishings, medical office

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: fast food, educational uses, bars & brewpubs

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: no new drive-through businesses, no new industrial or manufacturing uses, no new ground floor residential uses

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

x

CN Neighborhood Commercial

A low density commercial district where the customers will primarily access shops and services on foot or via alternative transportation.

Ex. of principally permitted uses include: Financial, insurance, real estate offices, Low Volume food uses and cafes

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: Convenience stores, athletic facilities, drug and department stores

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Manufacturing

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

x

CT Thoroughfare Commercial

This zone is only found close to state highways or other high traffic corridors and is set up to encourage high volume businesses.

Ex. of principally permitted uses include: banks, clothing and soft goods, hotels, nurseries, smaller professional and administrative uses

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: Business and technical schools, cemeteries, recreation facilities, community care facilities, drive ins and drive thrus, social clubs

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Heavy industry

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

x

PA Professional and Administrative Office

A buffer between a major thoroughfare and a low density residential neighborhood, this district is set up to encourage daytime, low volume professional uses.

Ex. of principally permitted uses include: Most financial, insurance and real estate office, galleries and medical office (except vets / kennels)

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: Vets, Medical Clinics, Schools and Churches

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Heavy Industry

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

x

IG General Industrial

The primary place for making and assembling items for distribution and wholesale. Only found in Harvey West and the far Westside.

Ex. of principally permitted uses include: Fabrication, Laborotories, Repairs, Alterations, Assembly and R&D

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: Retail Uses, Chemical and Paper production, Rubber and Metal fabrication, Medical Marijuana Dispensaries

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Any manufacturing use involving the primary production of products from new materials found to be incompatible with the neighborhood or the city as a whole based on noise, odor, air quality or other adverse environmental impact shall be prohibited.

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

x

CB Beach Commercial

Uses that primarily serve visitors near the beach.

Ex. of principally permitted uses include: Ice cream parlor, Surf shop, and bike rental.

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include:Tattoo parlor, Heavy manufacturing, and Medical Marijuana clinic.

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

Please note how the prior use of your chosen site compares to your intended use.

If you read the full definition of your site's zoning district, try to understand if and how your intended use is permitted.

City of Santa Cruz
Business Improvement Assessments (BIA) Calculator

What are Business Improvement Assessments?

Your Business Improvement Assessments are spent exclusively on promoting and improving the downtown area. The Assessments are collected by the City of Santa Cruz and forwarded directly to the Downtown Association of Santa Cruz. Learn more about the Downtown Association of Santa Cruz.

BIAs are based on several factors, including the size of your business. Enter your business's square footage, e.g., 1000

BIAs are also based on the type of business you operate. Select one of the following business categories:

BIAs are also based on the location of your business. Enter your street address

item.title: Use Permits - 4
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded:
The type of use permit you need is dependent on the way your zoning district permits your use.

If what you do is Principally Permitted all you need is a zoning clearance ⇣. This is the simplest form of a use permit.

x

More information coming soon.

If your use is not principally permitted you will need either an Administrative Use Permit or a Special Use Permit ⇣.

x

Admin Use Permit(AUP): This kind of application requires more staff analysis, and more information from the applicant. These permits entail a public hearing before the Zoning Administrator, and can take approximately 6-8 weeks to work their way through to completion.

Special Use Permit(SUP): Requires a high level of scrutiny, typically due to the size of the project and its impact on the neighborhood. These applications go to Planning Commission, whose decision is ratified by the City Council. SUPs take 2-3 months.

If your use is not permitted, you should probably ⇣ pick another spot.

x

Changing the Zoning is very difficult, rare and takes years. It is not recommended, but you are welcome to contact the planning department for more information.

item.title: Guide
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded:
This guide will explain what the city of Santa Cruz requires to start and locate a business.

County, State and Federal agencies might have needs too. Please be sure to satisfy their regulations.

x

This guide will try to explain what other agencies expect from you. Here are a few things off the bat:

1.If the name of your business does not contain your last name you will need to apply to county for a Fictitious business name (FBN).

For example, if your businees is called "Smith’s Tanning" a FBN is NOT needed, but if it is called "Jamaica Me Tan" a FBN is needed.

More information about State & Federal regulations coming soon!

At the end of the guide you will be able to ask Planning for information specific to you.

Skip to the Query form here if you like, but the guide is only 10 pages and will give you a good base for understanding the gist of permitting in Santa Cruz.

Let's get started.

item.title: Apply
item.dc:creator: opencounter
item.content:encoded: If you're starting a home-based business in Santa Cruz, fill out this form: Zoning Clearance Street City State Zip and Business License 1. Fill out this form. 2. Are you a corporation, partnership, LLC, or a trust? Please attach a list of officers or partners. 3. Are you a non-profit or tax-exempt organization? Please attach a copy of the letter from the Internal Revenue Service or the California State Franchise Tax Board as evidence of your current tax exempt status.

TK TK Special Use Permit requires a high level of scrutiny, typically due to the size of the project and its impact on the neighborhood. These applications go to Planning Commission, whose decision is ratified by the City Council. SUPs take 2-3 months.

TK TKAdmin Use Permit – this kind of application requires more staff analysis, and requires more information from the applicant. These permits require a public hearing before the Zoning Administrator, and take approximately 6-8 weeks to work their way through to completion.

The next 10 pages will explain what the city of Santa Cruz requires to start and locate a business.

At the end you will be able to ask Planning for information specific to you. Skip to the Query form here if you like.

Let's get started.

item.title: checklist
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded:
abstract check list?

Here is a summary of the issues that you must satisfy to open a business:

· Your zoning district permits your use. · Your intensity of use is allowed in your location. · All parking requirements are met. · Any unique requirements related to your type of use are met. · All tenant improvements are permitted and meet the building code. · Obtain a use permit from Planning. · Obtain a business license from Finance.

item.title: Summary - 9
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded:
To sum up.

If you are starting a business in Santa Cruz you must:

1. Satisfy Non-city regulations. 2. Get a Use permit from Planning. 3. Be sure tenant improvements are approved by the Building department. 4. Obtain a business licence from Finance.

var queryTask = new esri.tasks.QueryTask("http://gis.cityofsantacruz.com/ArcGIS/rest/services/AddressSeach/MapServer/0");
var query = new esri.tasks.Query();
query.returnGeometry = true;
query.outFields = ["*"];

function executeQuery(address){
	var result;
	while(address.indexOf("  ") > -1){
		address = address.replace("  "," ");
	}
	var lcadd = address.toLowerCase();
	// filter addresses which end with ", Santa Cruz, CA" but not "Santa Cruz St"
	if(lcadd.indexOf("santa cruz") != -1){
		if(lcadd.lastIndexOf("santa cruz") > lcadd.lastIndexOf("st")){
			address = address.substring(0, lcadd.lastIndexOf("santa cruz"));
		}
	}
	while(address.indexOf(",") > -1){
		address = address.replace(",","");
	}
	lcadd = address.toLowerCase();

	// abbreviate addresses to match GIS data
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" street") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" street") + 3);
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" avenue") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" avenue") + 4);
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" drive") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" drive") + 3);
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" circle") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" circle") + 4);
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" lane") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" lane")) + " Ln";
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" boulevard") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" boulevard")) + " Blvd";
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" court") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" court")) + " Ct";
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" place") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" place")) + " Pl";
	}
 	address = address.replace(/^s+|s+$/g,"");

	query.where = "ADD_ LIKE upper ('%" + address + "%')";
	queryTask.execute(query, function(results){
        if(results.features.length == 0){
        	// if address lookup fails, turn text box red
			document.getElementById("address").style.backgroundColor = "#f44";
		}
		else{
			document.getElementById("address").style.backgroundColor = "#fff";
			var zone = results.features[0].attributes['Zoning1'];
			var street = results.features[0].attributes['ADD_'];
			var usecode = results.features[0].attributes['USECDDESC'];

			var latlng = new L.LatLng(results.features[0].geometry.y, results.features[0].geometry.x);
			//console.log(latlng);
			
			var marker = new L.Marker(latlng);
			map.addLayer(marker);
			marker.bindPopup(street + "
Zone: " + zone + "
Current Use: " + usecode).openPopup();
			
			// test: store zone and use code as a cookie
			setCookie("zone_and_use", zone + "|" + usecode, 21);
		}
	});
}

var map;
var _tilejson;
wax.tilejson('http://a.tiles.mapbox.com/v3/tamaracfa.map-lhp1bb4f.jsonp',
	function(tilejson) {
		_tilejson = tilejson;
		map = new L.Map('map-div', { scrollWheelZoom: false, maxZoom: 17 })
    		.addLayer(new wax.leaf.connector(tilejson))
    		.setView(new L.LatLng(36.9749, -122.0263), 13);

		wax.leaf.interaction()
			.map(map)
			.tilejson(tilejson)
			.on(wax.tooltip().animate(false).parent(map._container).events())
	}
);


function codeAddress() {
	var address = document.getElementById("address").value;
	executeQuery(address);
}

function checkForEnter(e){
	if(e.keyCode == 13){
		codeAddress();
	}
}

// test: cookie to store zone and use code of address
function setCookie(c_name,value,exdays){
	var exdate=new Date();
	exdate.setDate(exdate.getDate() + exdays);
	var c_value=escape(value) + ((exdays==null) ? "" : "; expires="+exdate.toUTCString());
	document.cookie=c_name + "=" + c_value;
}


    
	


				

		
			

				
You can check a site’s zoning and prior use by entering the address here:





Example: 1367 Pacific Avenue
















Powered by Leaflet — Terms & Feedback



All zones are defined by title 24 of the <a http:="" www.codepublishing.com="" ca="" santacruz="" "="" target="_blank">Municipal code. 







CBD Central Business District »

CBD-E Subdistrict Lower Pacific Ave »

CC Community Commercial »

CN Neighborhood Commercia »

CT Thoroughfare Commercial »

PA Professional and Administrative Office »

CB Beach Commercial »

IG General Industrial »






CBD Central Business District

Only found in Downtown Santa Cruz, this zoning allows most retail and food uses. Developed in the aftermath of the Loma Prieta earthquake, this district also includes a shared parking and marketing resources and has lower development impact fees.

Ex. of permitted uses include: restaurants, shoes, boutiques, ice cream parlors, cafes and bike shops

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: barber shops, laundries and cleaning establishments, business and technical schools

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Tattoo parlor, Heavy manufacturing, and ground floor professional and administrative uses along Pacific Avenue. 

Please read the Municipal Code & the downtown recovery plan

X Close




CBD-E Subdistrict Lower Pacific Ave


Set up to help bridge the downtown to the beach area, this district encourages mixed uses that include commercial and recreational businesses. 

Ex. of permitted uses include: art galleries, restaurants, boutiques, cafes and dance studios 

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: bars, meeting halls, off street parking facilities, convenience stores. 

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: mortuaries, manufacturing

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.


X Close




CC Community Commercial

Primary zoning for most major commercial corridors, this district is set up to permit many different types of uses.

Ex. of permitted uses include: Apparel stores, auto supply, restaurants, home furnishings, medical office

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: fast food, educational uses, bars & brewpubs

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: no new drive-through businesses, no new industrial or manufacturing uses, no new ground floor residential uses

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

X Close




CN Neighborhood Commercial

A low density commercial district where the customers will primarily access shops and services on foot or via alternative transportation.

Ex. of permitted uses include: Financial, insurance, real estate offices, Low Volume food uses and cafes

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: Convenience stores, athletic facilities, drug and department stores

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Manufacturing

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

X Close




CT Thoroughfare Commercial

This zone is only found close to state highways or other high traffic corridors and is set up to encourage high volume businesses.

Ex. of permitted uses include: banks, clothing and soft goods, hotels, nurseries, smaller professional and administrative uses

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: Business and technical schools, cemeteries, recreation facilities, community care facilities, drive ins and drive thrus, social clubs

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Heavy industry

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

X Close




PA Professional and Administrative Office

A buffer between a major thoroughfare and a low density residential neighborhood, this district is set up to encourage daytime, low volume professional uses.

Ex. of permitted uses include: Most financial, insurance and real estate office, galleries and medical office (except vets / kennels)

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: Vets, Medical Clinics, Schools and Churches

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Heavy Industry

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

X Close




IG General Industrial

he primary place for making and assembling items for distribution and wholesale. Only found in Harvey West and the far Westside.

Ex. of permitted uses include: Fabrication, Laborotories, Repairs, Alterations, Assembly and R&D

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: Retail Uses, Chemical and Paper production, Rubber and Metal fabrication, Medical Marijuana Dispensaries

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Any manufacturing use involving the primary production of products from new materials found to be incompatible with the neighborhood or the city as a whole based on noise, odor, air quality or other adverse environmental impact shall be prohibited.

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

X Close




CB Beach Commercial

Uses that primarily serve visitors near the beach.

Ex. of permitted uses include: Ice cream parlor, Surf shop, and bike rental.

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include:Tattoo parlor, Heavy manufacturing, and Medical Marijuana clinc.

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

X Close


Read about the zoning district that your desired location is in.

Try to determine if your use falls under “Principally Permitted Uses”, “Use permit requirement” or is not mentioned.

If it falls under “Use permit requirement” check is it under: 1.Administrative use permit or 2.Special use permit?

If your use or a similar use was not mentioned as allowed, the use is likely NOT permitted.

Also note how the prior use of the space matches what you plan to do.

item.title: describe intent
item.content:encoded: I think there needs to be more of a blatant description of what exactly this website will do for the user. At the end you describe it as a GUIDE. I think it would be helpful to indicate the guide aspect with "This is an online guide designed to walk you through necessary steps to opening a small business in Santa Cruz. Along the way you'll find necessary information and forms you might need to fill out." or something like that...

item.title: Wonderful first impression!
item.content:encoded: The first impression of the site is that it is beautiful. Not a govt site (in a great way). The whitespace makes me feel way less stressed and I can consume the info that is there. I love subtle use of animations that allow me to see so much more about the other organizations I should contact if I'm doing something this page can't help with - instead of just a link, I get all the info I need from about those other departments without having to go to their crappy sites - smart!

A good tip for finding a location that permits your use is to pick a space with a prior use as similar to yours as possible.

If you are opening a restaurant try to go into a space that held a restaurant.

If you are opening a yoga studio try to go into, say, a karate studio.

This will make it more likely that your use will be approved.

If the past use matches your use, the zoning will match and parking will likely not be an issue.

dojo.require("esri.tasks.query");
var queryTask = new esri.tasks.QueryTask("http://gis.cityofsantacruz.com/ArcGIS/rest/services/AddressSeach/MapServer/0");
var query = new esri.tasks.Query();
query.returnGeometry = true;
query.outFields = ["*"];

function executeQuery(address){
	var result;
	while(address.indexOf("  ") > -1){
		address = address.replace("  "," ");
	}
	var lcadd = address.toLowerCase();
	// filter addresses which end with ", Santa Cruz, CA" but not "Santa Cruz St"
	if(lcadd.indexOf("santa cruz") != -1){
		if(lcadd.lastIndexOf("santa cruz") > lcadd.lastIndexOf("st")){
			address = address.substring(0, lcadd.lastIndexOf("santa cruz"));
		}
	}
	while(address.indexOf(",") > -1){
		address = address.replace(",","");
	}
	lcadd = address.toLowerCase();

	// abbreviate addresses to match GIS data
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" street") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" street") + 3);
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" avenue") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" avenue") + 4);
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" drive") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" drive") + 3);
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" circle") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" circle") + 4);
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" lane") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" lane")) + " Ln";
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" boulevard") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" boulevard")) + " Blvd";
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" court") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" court")) + " Ct";
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" place") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" place")) + " Pl";
	}
 	address = address.replace(/^s+|s+$/g,"");

	query.where = "ADD_ LIKE upper ('%" + address + "%')";
	queryTask.execute(query, function(results){
        if(results.features.length == 0){
        	// if address lookup fails, turn text box red
			document.getElementById("address").style.backgroundColor = "#f44";
		}
		else{
			document.getElementById("address").style.backgroundColor = "#fff";
			var zone = results.features[0].attributes['Zoning1'];
			var street = results.features[0].attributes['ADD_'];
			var usecode = results.features[0].attributes['USECDDESC'];

			var latlng = new L.LatLng(results.features[0].geometry.y, results.features[0].geometry.x);
			//console.log(latlng);
			
			var marker = new L.Marker(latlng);
			map.addLayer(marker);
			marker.bindPopup(street + "
Zone: " + zone + "
Current Use: " + usecode).openPopup();
			
			// test: store zone and use code as a cookie
			//setCookie("zone_and_use", zone + "|" + usecode, 21);
			Cookies.defaults = {
				path: '/',
				expires: 60 * 60 * 24 * 21,
				secure: false
			}
			Cookies.set('address', document.getElementById("address").value );
			Cookies.set('zone_and_use', zone + "|" + usecode);
		}
	});
}

var map;
var _tilejson;
wax.tilejson('http://a.tiles.mapbox.com/v3/tamaracfa.map-lhp1bb4f.jsonp',
	function(tilejson) {
		_tilejson = tilejson;
		map = new L.Map('map-div', { scrollWheelZoom: false, maxZoom: 17 })
    		.addLayer(new wax.leaf.connector(tilejson))
    		.setView(new L.LatLng(36.9749, -122.0263), 13);

		wax.leaf.interaction()
			.map(map)
			.tilejson(tilejson)
			.on(wax.tooltip().animate(false).parent(map._container).events())
	}
);


function codeAddress() {
	var address = document.getElementById("address").value;
	executeQuery(address);
}

function checkForEnter(e){
	if(e.keyCode == 13){
		codeAddress();
	}
}

    
	


				

		
			

				
You can check a site’s zoning and prior use by entering the address here:





Example: 1367 Pacific Avenue












1200 PACIFIC AVE
Zone: CBD - CENTRAL BUSINESS DIS
Current Use: COMM/IND/AGR//INCOMP









Powered by Leaflet — Terms & Feedback



All zones are defined by title 24 of the <a http:="" www.codepublishing.com="" ca="" santacruz="" "="" target="_blank">Municipal code. 







CBD Central Business District »

CBD-E Subdistrict Lower Pacific Ave »

CC Community Commercial »

CN Neighborhood Commercia »

CT Thoroughfare Commercial »

PA Professional and Administrative Office »

CB Beach Commercial »

IG General Industrial »






CBD Central Business District

Only found in Downtown Santa Cruz, this zoning allows most retail and food uses. Developed in the aftermath of the Loma Prieta earthquake, this district also includes a shared parking and marketing resources and has lower development impact fees.

Ex. of permitted uses include: restaurants, shoes, boutiques, ice cream parlors, cafes and bike shops

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: barber shops, laundries and cleaning establishments, business and technical schools

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Tattoo parlor, Heavy manufacturing, and ground floor professional and administrative uses along Pacific Avenue. 

Please read the Municipal Code & the downtown recovery plan

X Close




CBD-E Subdistrict Lower Pacific Ave


Set up to help bridge the downtown to the beach area, this district encourages mixed uses that include commercial and recreational businesses. 

Ex. of permitted uses include: art galleries, restaurants, boutiques, cafes and dance studios 

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: bars, meeting halls, off street parking facilities, convenience stores. 

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: mortuaries, manufacturing

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.


X Close




CC Community Commercial

Primary zoning for most major commercial corridors, this district is set up to permit many different types of uses.

Ex. of permitted uses include: Apparel stores, auto supply, restaurants, home furnishings, medical office

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: fast food, educational uses, bars & brewpubs

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: no new drive-through businesses, no new industrial or manufacturing uses, no new ground floor residential uses

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

X Close




CN Neighborhood Commercial

A low density commercial district where the customers will primarily access shops and services on foot or via alternative transportation.

Ex. of permitted uses include: Financial, insurance, real estate offices, Low Volume food uses and cafes

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: Convenience stores, athletic facilities, drug and department stores

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Manufacturing

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

X Close




CT Thoroughfare Commercial

This zone is only found close to state highways or other high traffic corridors and is set up to encourage high volume businesses.

Ex. of permitted uses include: banks, clothing and soft goods, hotels, nurseries, smaller professional and administrative uses

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: Business and technical schools, cemeteries, recreation facilities, community care facilities, drive ins and drive thrus, social clubs

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Heavy industry

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

X Close




PA Professional and Administrative Office

A buffer between a major thoroughfare and a low density residential neighborhood, this district is set up to encourage daytime, low volume professional uses.

Ex. of permitted uses include: Most financial, insurance and real estate office, galleries and medical office (except vets / kennels)

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: Vets, Medical Clinics, Schools and Churches

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Heavy Industry

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

X Close




IG General Industrial

he primary place for making and assembling items for distribution and wholesale. Only found in Harvey West and the far Westside.

Ex. of permitted uses include: Fabrication, Laborotories, Repairs, Alterations, Assembly and R&D

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: Retail Uses, Chemical and Paper production, Rubber and Metal fabrication, Medical Marijuana Dispensaries

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Any manufacturing use involving the primary production of products from new materials found to be incompatible with the neighborhood or the city as a whole based on noise, odor, air quality or other adverse environmental impact shall be prohibited.

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

X Close




CB Beach Commercial

Uses that primarily serve visitors near the beach.

Ex. of permitted uses include: Ice cream parlor, Surf shop, and bike rental.

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include:Tattoo parlor, Heavy manufacturing, and Medical Marijuana clinc.

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.

X Close


Note how the prior use of the site compares to your use.

If you read the full definition of the site’s zoning district, note how your use is permitted.

A gym has a more “intense use” than a warehouse. This means more parking is needed and means more cars on the road.
If the prior use of your site is similar or less intense ⇣ than what you do, this doesn’t affect you. Move along!
x
Here are some businesses listed from light to intense use: Warehouse < Shoe store < Restaurant
More information coming soon.
But, if you need to change a space to a more “intense use” you must pay for the impacts you’ll be causing. Please read more about it ⇣.
x
This is a complicated concept. In California, it’s our responsibility to mitigate the impact of changes of use if the “intensity” of use increases. This means accounting for more traffic, parking and people using the space.
It costs a lot to keep the traffic of Santa Cruz flowing.
If your business has a higher traffic need than your space allows it is your responsibility to pay into a fund that helps traffic improvements. This is done by a one time charge called Traffic Impact Fee (TIF). TIF helps pay for things like wider lanes and signalized intersections.
TIF can be $1000 to $200,000. This is why we reccomend picking a location with a similar use to yours.
The fee is based on the number of trips your use switch causes. Here is a tool that helps estimate the fee:
If you love a space with a serious TIF you should talk to The office of Economic Development. They will try to help.
x

'https://ssl' : 'http://www') + '.google-analytics.com/ga.js'; var s = document.getElementsByTagName('script')[0]; s.parentNode.insertBefore(ga, s); })();
A business must provide sufficient parking.
If you don’t have enough spaces, your customers will use the street, which will block traffic, or use other businesses’ spots, which is not fair.
Your use affects the parking spaces required ⇣. More people buy food than couches, so a super market requires more parking than a furniture store.
x
Here is the table that is used to calculate the number of parking spots needed for space and use.
Use
Spaces Required
a.
Automobile or machinery sales and service garages
1 for each 400 square feet floor area
b.
Banks without automatic teller machines
1 for each 400 square feet floor area
c.
Banks with automatic teller machines
1 for each 400 square feet floor area; plus 1.5 for each machine
d.
Business and professional offices, excluding medical and dental offices
1 for each 300 square feet floor area
e.
Billiard parlors
1.5 for each table
f.
Boarding homes for the aged
1 for each 5 beds, plus 1 for each employee
g.
Children’s homes
1 for each 5 beds, plus 1 for each employee
h.
Houses of worship
1 for each 3.5 seats in the sanctuary
i.
Dancehalls and assembly halls without fixed seats, exhibition halls, except church assembly rooms in conjunction with auditoriums
1 for each 3 persons of design occupancy load
j.
Family daycare and foster family homes
1 for every 5 guests, plus 1 for the resident owner or manager
k.
Funeral homes, mortuaries
1 for each 5 seats of the aggregate number of seats provided in all assembly rooms
l.
Furniture and appliance stores, household equipment
1 for each 800 square feet of sales floor area
m.
Community care residential facilities
1 for each 5 guests, plus 1 for the manager, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
n.
Hospitals
1 for each bed, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
o.
Hotels, motels
1 for each unit intended for separate occupancy, plus 1 for the resident owner or manager
p.
Institutions for the aged
1 for every 5 guests, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
q.
Manufacturing plants, bottling plants, processing plants, packaging plants, furniture repair
1 for each 500 square feet of floor area
r.
Medical and dental clinics and offices
1 for each 200 square feet of floor area
s.
Medical (or convalescent) hospitals
1 for each 5 beds, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
t.
Nursing homes
1 for every 5 guests, plus 1 for the resident manager, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
u.
Physical fitness facilities
Multi-program:
1 space for each 100 square feet of floor area
Single-program:
• aerobics:
1 space for each 50 square feet of floor area
• basketball; volleyball:
1 space for each 3 persons of occupancy
• lap pool:
2 spaces per lane plus 1 space for each 300 square feet of non-pool floor area
• weightlifting:
1 space for each 250 feet of floor area
Physical fitness facilities with more than 15,000 square feet of floor area shall provide an additional 10 percent of the total number of required parking spaces
v.
Physical therapy
1 space per 200 square feet of floor area. In addition, 1 space per 50 square feet of pool (water) area
If the resulting number of parking spots contains a fraction and that fraction is greater than half you must round up and add a full parking space.
x
If you are located downtown ⇣, you don’t need to provide parking, but you must pay for it.
x
More information on coming soon.
x

*If you’re building a hotel or need a subdivision map, sorry, this site is not for you. Please visit the Planning Department » or contact Economic Development ».

Closed Fridays.

item.title: OpenCounter logo?
item.dc:creator: tamara
item.content:encoded: Is the OpenCounter with clock in the "O" a Logo? If so, should it be further down on the page / why is it placed front and center? Its a little misleading to the eye, makes me want to click on it, and then nothing happens.

A good tip for finding a location that permits your use is to pick a space with a prior use as similar to yours as possible.

If you are opening a restaurant try to go into a space that held a restaurant.

If you are opening a yoga studio try to go into, say, a karate studio.

This will make it more likely that your use will be approved.

If the past use matches your use, the zoning will match and parking will likely not be an issue.

This guide will explain what the city of Santa Cruz requires to start and locate a business.
County, State and Federal agencies might have needs too. Please be sure to satisfy their regulations.
x
This guide will try to explain what other agencies expect from you. Here are a few things off the bat:
1.If the name of your business does not contain your last name you will need to apply to county for a Fictitious business name (FBN).
For example, if your businees is called “Smith’s Tanning” a FBN is NOT needed, but
if it is called “Jamaica Me Tan” a FBN is needed.
More information about State & Federal regulations coming soon!
At the end of the guide you will be able to ask Planning for information specific to you.
Skip to the Query form here if you like, but the guide is only 10 pages and will give you a good base for understanding the gist of permitting in Santa Cruz.
Let’s get started.

dojo.require("esri.tasks.query");
var queryTask = new esri.tasks.QueryTask("http://gis.cityofsantacruz.com/ArcGIS/rest/services/AddressSeach/MapServer/0");
var query = new esri.tasks.Query();
query.returnGeometry = true;
query.outFields = ["*"];

function executeQuery(address){
	var result;
	while(address.indexOf("  ") > -1){
		address = address.replace("  "," ");
	}
	var lcadd = address.toLowerCase();
	// filter addresses which end with ", Santa Cruz, CA" but not "Santa Cruz St"
	if(lcadd.indexOf("santa cruz") != -1){
		if(lcadd.lastIndexOf("santa cruz") > lcadd.lastIndexOf("st")){
			address = address.substring(0, lcadd.lastIndexOf("santa cruz"));
		}
	}
	while(address.indexOf(",") > -1){
		address = address.replace(",","");
	}
	lcadd = address.toLowerCase();

	// abbreviate addresses to match GIS data
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" street") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" street") + 3);
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" avenue") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" avenue") + 4);
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" drive") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" drive") + 3);
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" circle") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" circle") + 4);
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" lane") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" lane")) + " Ln";
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" boulevard") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" boulevard")) + " Blvd";
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" court") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" court")) + " Ct";
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" place") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" place")) + " Pl";
	}
 	address = address.replace(/^s+|s+$/g,"");

	query.where = "ADD_ LIKE upper ('%" + address + "%')";
	queryTask.execute(query, function(results){
        if(results.features.length == 0){
        	// if address lookup fails, turn text box red
			document.getElementById("address").style.backgroundColor = "#f44";
		}
		else{
			document.getElementById("address").style.backgroundColor = "#fff";
			var zone = results.features[0].attributes['Zoning1'];
			var street = results.features[0].attributes['ADD_'];
			var usecode = results.features[0].attributes['USECDDESC'];

			var latlng = new L.LatLng(results.features[0].geometry.y, results.features[0].geometry.x);
			//console.log(latlng);
			
			var marker = new L.Marker(latlng);
			map.addLayer(marker);
			marker.bindPopup(street + "
Zone: " + zone + "
Current Use (Prior Use): " + usecode).openPopup();
			
			// test: store zone and use code as a cookie
			//setCookie("zone_and_use", zone + "|" + usecode, 21);
			Cookies.defaults = {
				path: '/',
				expires: 60 * 60 * 24 * 21,
				secure: false
			}
			Cookies.set('address', document.getElementById("address").value );
			Cookies.set('zone_and_use', zone + "|" + usecode);
		}
	});
}

var map;
var _tilejson;
wax.tilejson('http://a.tiles.mapbox.com/v3/tamaracfa.map-lhp1bb4f.jsonp',
	function(tilejson) {
		_tilejson = tilejson;
		map = new L.Map('map-div', { scrollWheelZoom: false, maxZoom: 17 })
    		.addLayer(new wax.leaf.connector(tilejson))
    		.setView(new L.LatLng(36.9749, -122.0263), 13);

		wax.leaf.interaction()
			.map(map)
			.tilejson(tilejson)
			.on(wax.tooltip().animate(false).parent(map._container).events())
	}
);


function codeAddress() {
	var address = document.getElementById("address").value;
	executeQuery(address);
}

function checkForEnter(e){
	if(e.keyCode == 13){
		codeAddress();
	}
}

    
	


				

		
			

				
You can check a site’s zoning and prior use by entering the address here:





Example: 1367 Pacific Avenue
















Powered by Leaflet — Terms & Feedback



All zones are defined by title 24 of the <a http:="" www.codepublishing.com="" ca="" santacruz="" "="" target="_blank">Municipal code. 







CBD Central Business District ⇣

CBD-E Subdistrict Lower Pacific Ave ⇣

CC Community Commercial ⇣

CN Neighborhood Commercia ⇣

CT Thoroughfare Commercial ⇣

PA Professional and Administrative Office ⇣

CB Beach Commercial ⇣

IG General Industrial ⇣






x

CBD Central Business District

Only found in Downtown Santa Cruz, this zoning allows most retail and food uses. Developed in the aftermath of the Loma Prieta earthquake, this district also includes a shared parking and marketing resources and has lower development impact fees.

Ex. of principally permitted uses include: restaurants, shoes, boutiques, ice cream parlors, cafes and bike shops

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: barber shops, laundries and cleaning establishments, business and technical schools

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Tattoo parlor, Heavy manufacturing, and ground floor professional and administrative uses along Pacific Avenue. 

Please read the Municipal Code & the downtown recovery plan




x

CBD-E Subdistrict Lower Pacific Ave


Set up to help bridge the downtown to the beach area, this district encourages mixed uses that include commercial and recreational businesses. 

Ex. of principally permitted uses include: art galleries, restaurants, boutiques, cafes and dance studios 

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: bars, meeting halls, off street parking facilities, convenience stores. 

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: mortuaries, manufacturing

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.





x

CC Community Commercial

Primary zoning for most major commercial corridors, this district is set up to permit many different types of uses.

Ex. of principally permitted uses include: Apparel stores, auto supply, restaurants, home furnishings, medical office

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: fast food, educational uses, bars & brewpubs

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: no new drive-through businesses, no new industrial or manufacturing uses, no new ground floor residential uses

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.




x

CN Neighborhood Commercial

A low density commercial district where the customers will primarily access shops and services on foot or via alternative transportation.

Ex. of principally permitted uses include: Financial, insurance, real estate offices, Low Volume food uses and cafes

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: Convenience stores, athletic facilities, drug and department stores

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Manufacturing

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.




x

CT Thoroughfare Commercial

This zone is only found close to state highways or other high traffic corridors and is set up to encourage high volume businesses.

Ex. of principally permitted uses include: banks, clothing and soft goods, hotels, nurseries, smaller professional and administrative uses

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: Business and technical schools, cemeteries, recreation facilities, community care facilities, drive ins and drive thrus, social clubs

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Heavy industry

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.




x

PA Professional and Administrative Office

A buffer between a major thoroughfare and a low density residential neighborhood, this district is set up to encourage daytime, low volume professional uses.

Ex. of principally permitted uses include: Most financial, insurance and real estate office, galleries and medical office (except vets / kennels)

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: Vets, Medical Clinics, Schools and Churches

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Heavy Industry

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.




x

IG General Industrial

he primary place for making and assembling items for distribution and wholesale. Only found in Harvey West and the far Westside.

Ex. of principally permitted uses include: Fabrication, Laborotories, Repairs, Alterations, Assembly and R&D

Ex. of uses that will require more staff review: Retail Uses, Chemical and Paper production, Rubber and Metal fabrication, Medical Marijuana Dispensaries

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include: Any manufacturing use involving the primary production of products from new materials found to be incompatible with the neighborhood or the city as a whole based on noise, odor, air quality or other adverse environmental impact shall be prohibited.

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.




x

CB Beach Commercial

Uses that primarily serve visitors near the beach.

Ex. of principally permitted uses include: Ice cream parlor, Surf shop, and bike rental.

Ex. of uses that are not allowed include:Tattoo parlor, Heavy manufacturing, and Medical Marijuana clinic.

Please read the Municipal Code for a complete definition.


Please note how the prior use of your chosen site compares to your intended use.

If you read the full definition of your site’s zoning district, try to understand if and how your intended use is permitted.

The type of use permit you need is dependent on the way your zoning district permits your use.
If what you do is Principally Permitted all you need is a zoning clearance ⇣. This is the simplest form of a use permit.
x
More information coming soon.
If your use is not principally permitted you will need either an Administrative Use Permit or a Special Use Permit ⇣.
x
Admin Use Permit(AUP): This kind of application requires more staff analysis, and more information from the applicant. These permits entail a public hearing before the Zoning Administrator, and take approximately 6-8 weeks to work their way through to completion.
Special Use Permit(SUP): Requires a high level of scrutiny, typically due to the size of the project and its impact on the neighborhood. These applications go to Planning Commission, whose decision is ratified by the City Council. SUPs take 2-3 months.
If your use is not permitted, you should probably ⇣ pick another spot.
x
Changing the Zoning is very difficult, rare and takes years. It is not recommended, but you are welcome to contact the planning department for more information.

dojo.require("esri.tasks.query");
var queryTask = new esri.tasks.QueryTask("http://gis.cityofsantacruz.com/ArcGIS/rest/services/AddressSeach/MapServer/0");
var query = new esri.tasks.Query();
query.returnGeometry = true;
query.outFields = ["*"];

function executeQuery(address){
	var result;
	while(address.indexOf("  ") > -1){
		address = address.replace("  "," ");
	}
	var lcadd = address.toLowerCase();
	// filter addresses which end with ", Santa Cruz, CA" but not "Santa Cruz St"
	if(lcadd.indexOf("santa cruz") != -1){
		if(lcadd.lastIndexOf("santa cruz") > lcadd.lastIndexOf("st")){
			address = address.substring(0, lcadd.lastIndexOf("santa cruz"));
		}
	}
	while(address.indexOf(",") > -1){
		address = address.replace(",","");
	}
	lcadd = address.toLowerCase();

	// abbreviate addresses to match GIS data
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" street") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" street") + 3);
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" avenue") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" avenue") + 4);
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" drive") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" drive") + 3);
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" circle") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" circle") + 4);
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" lane") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" lane")) + " Ln";
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" boulevard") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" boulevard")) + " Blvd";
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" court") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" court")) + " Ct";
	}
	if(lcadd.indexOf(" place") > -1){
		address = address.substring(0, lcadd.indexOf(" place")) + " Pl";
	}
 	address = address.replace(/^s+|s+$/g,"");

	query.where = "ADD_ LIKE upper ('%" + address + "%')";
	queryTask.execute(query, function(results){
        if(results.features.length == 0){
        	// if address lookup fails, turn text box red
			document.getElementById("address").style.backgroundColor = "#f44";
		}
		else{
			document.getElementById("address").style.backgroundColor = "#fff";
			var zone = results.features[0].attributes['Zoning1'];
			var street = results.features[0].attributes['ADD_'];
			var usecode = results.features[0].attributes['USECDDESC'];

			var latlng = new L.LatLng(results.features[0].geometry.y, results.features[0].geometry.x);
			//console.log(latlng);
			
			var marker = new L.Marker(latlng);
			map.addLayer(marker);
			marker.bindPopup(street + "
Zone: " + zone + "
Current Use (Prior Use): " + usecode).openPopup();
			
			// test: store zone and use code as a cookie
			//setCookie("zone_and_use", zone + "|" + usecode, 21);
			Cookies.defaults = {
				path: '/',
				expires: 60 * 60 * 24 * 21,
				secure: false
			}
			Cookies.set('address', document.getElementById("address").value );
			Cookies.set('zone_and_use', zone + "|" + usecode);
		}
	});
}

var map;
var _tilejson;
wax.tilejson('http://a.tiles.mapbox.com/v3/tamaracfa.map-lhp1bb4f.jsonp',
	function(tilejson) {
		_tilejson = tilejson;
		map = new L.Map('map-div', { scrollWheelZoom: false, maxZoom: 17 })
    		.addLayer(new wax.leaf.connector(tilejson))
    		.setView(new L.LatLng(36.9749, -122.0263), 13);

		wax.leaf.interaction()
			.map(map)
			.tilejson(tilejson)
			.on(wax.tooltip().animate(false).parent(map._container).events())
	}
);


function codeAddress() {
	var address = document.getElementById("address").value;
	executeQuery(address);
}

function checkForEnter(e){
	if(e.keyCode == 13){
		codeAddress();
	}
}

'https://ssl' : 'http://www') + '.google-analytics.com/ga.js'; var s = document.getElementsByTagName('script')[0]; s.parentNode.insertBefore(ga, s); })();
A business must provide sufficient parking.
If you don’t have enough spaces, your customers will use the street, which will block traffic, or use other businesses’ spots, which is not fair.
Your use affects the parking spaces required ⇣. More people buy food than couches, so a super market requires more parking than a furniture store.
x
Here is the table that is used to calculate the number of parking spots needed for space and use.
Use
Spaces Required
a.
Automobile or machinery sales and service garages
1 for each 400 square feet floor area
b.
Banks without automatic teller machines
1 for each 400 square feet floor area
c.
Banks with automatic teller machines
1 for each 400 square feet floor area; plus 1.5 for each machine
d.
Business and professional offices, excluding medical and dental offices
1 for each 300 square feet floor area
e.
Billiard parlors
1.5 for each table
f.
Boarding homes for the aged
1 for each 5 beds, plus 1 for each employee
g.
Children’s homes
1 for each 5 beds, plus 1 for each employee
h.
Houses of worship
1 for each 3.5 seats in the sanctuary
i.
Dancehalls and assembly halls without fixed seats, exhibition halls, except church assembly rooms in conjunction with auditoriums
1 for each 3 persons of design occupancy load
j.
Family daycare and foster family homes
1 for every 5 guests, plus 1 for the resident owner or manager
k.
Funeral homes, mortuaries
1 for each 5 seats of the aggregate number of seats provided in all assembly rooms
l.
Furniture and appliance stores, household equipment
1 for each 800 square feet of sales floor area
m.
Community care residential facilities
1 for each 5 guests, plus 1 for the manager, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
n.
Hospitals
1 for each bed, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
o.
Hotels, motels
1 for each unit intended for separate occupancy, plus 1 for the resident owner or manager
p.
Institutions for the aged
1 for every 5 guests, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
q.
Manufacturing plants, bottling plants, processing plants, packaging plants, furniture repair
1 for each 500 square feet of floor area
r.
Medical and dental clinics and offices
1 for each 200 square feet of floor area
s.
Medical (or convalescent) hospitals
1 for each 5 beds, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
t.
Nursing homes
1 for every 5 guests, plus 1 for the resident manager, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
u.
Physical fitness facilities
Multi-program:
1 space for each 100 square feet of floor area
Single-program:
• aerobics:
1 space for each 50 square feet of floor area
• basketball; volleyball:
1 space for each 3 persons of occupancy
• lap pool:
2 spaces per lane plus 1 space for each 300 square feet of non-pool floor area
• weightlifting:
1 space for each 250 feet of floor area
Physical fitness facilities with more than 15,000 square feet of floor area shall provide an additional 10 percent of the total number of required parking spaces
v.
Physical therapy
1 space per 200 square feet of floor area. In addition, 1 space per 50 square feet of pool (water) area
If the resulting number of parking spots contains a fraction and that fraction is greater than half you must round up and add a full parking space.
x
If you are located downtown ⇣, you don’t need to provide parking, but you must pay for it.
x
More information on coming soon.
x

item.title: Parking Language Fix
item.content:encoded:
not technically accurate to say "If you are located downtown ⇣, you don’t need to provide parking, but you must pay for it."
better to say
downtown works a little differently. It has a shared parking model with reduced requirements. If you don't have off street parking, you can pay into a shared fund that runs the City garages and lots.

A business must provide sufficient parking.
If you don’t have enough spaces, your customers will use the street, which will block traffic, or use other businesses’ spots, which is not fair.
Your use affects the parking spaces required ⇣. More people buy food than couches, so a super market requires more parking than a furniture store.
x
Here is the table that is used to calculate the number of parking spots needed for space and use.
Use
Spaces Required
a.
Automobile or machinery sales and service garages
1 for each 400 square feet floor area
b.
Banks without automatic teller machines
1 for each 400 square feet floor area
c.
Banks with automatic teller machines
1 for each 400 square feet floor area; plus 1.5 for each machine
d.
Business and professional offices, excluding medical and dental offices
1 for each 300 square feet floor area
e.
Billiard parlors
1.5 for each table
f.
Boarding homes for the aged
1 for each 5 beds, plus 1 for each employee
g.
Children’s homes
1 for each 5 beds, plus 1 for each employee
h.
Houses of worship
1 for each 3.5 seats in the sanctuary
i.
Dancehalls and assembly halls without fixed seats, exhibition halls, except church assembly rooms in conjunction with auditoriums
1 for each 3 persons of design occupancy load
j.
Family daycare and foster family homes
1 for every 5 guests, plus 1 for the resident owner or manager
k.
Funeral homes, mortuaries
1 for each 5 seats of the aggregate number of seats provided in all assembly rooms
l.
Furniture and appliance stores, household equipment
1 for each 800 square feet of sales floor area
m.
Community care residential facilities
1 for each 5 guests, plus 1 for the manager, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
n.
Hospitals
1 for each bed, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
o.
Hotels, motels
1 for each unit intended for separate occupancy, plus 1 for the resident owner or manager
p.
Institutions for the aged
1 for every 5 guests, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
q.
Manufacturing plants, bottling plants, processing plants, packaging plants, furniture repair
1 for each 500 square feet of floor area
r.
Medical and dental clinics and offices
1 for each 200 square feet of floor area
s.
Medical (or convalescent) hospitals
1 for each 5 beds, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
t.
Nursing homes
1 for every 5 guests, plus 1 for the resident manager, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
u.
Physical fitness facilities
Multi-program:
1 space for each 100 square feet of floor area
Single-program:
• aerobics:
1 space for each 50 square feet of floor area
• basketball; volleyball:
1 space for each 3 persons of occupancy
• lap pool:
2 spaces per lane plus 1 space for each 300 square feet of non-pool floor area
• weightlifting:
1 space for each 250 feet of floor area
Physical fitness facilities with more than 15,000 square feet of floor area shall provide an additional 10 percent of the total number of required parking spaces
v.
Physical therapy
1 space per 200 square feet of floor area. In addition, 1 space per 50 square feet of pool (water) area
If the resulting number of parking spots contains a fraction and that fraction is greater than half you must round up and add a full parking space.
x
If you are located downtown ⇣, you don’t need to provide parking, but you must pay for it.

'https://ssl' : 'http://www') + '.google-analytics.com/ga.js'; var s = document.getElementsByTagName('script')[0]; s.parentNode.insertBefore(ga, s); })();
A business must provide sufficient parking.
If you don’t have enough spaces, your customers will use the street, which will block traffic, or use other businesses’ spots, which is not fair.
Your use affects the parking spaces required ⇣. More people buy food than couches, so a super market requires more parking than a furniture store.
x
Here is the table that is used to calculate the number of parking spots needed for space and use.
Use
Spaces Required
a.
Automobile or machinery sales and service garages
1 for each 400 square feet floor area
b.
Banks without automatic teller machines
1 for each 400 square feet floor area
c.
Banks with automatic teller machines
1 for each 400 square feet floor area; plus 1.5 for each machine
d.
Business and professional offices, excluding medical and dental offices
1 for each 300 square feet floor area
e.
Billiard parlors
1.5 for each table
f.
Boarding homes for the aged
1 for each 5 beds, plus 1 for each employee
g.
Children’s homes
1 for each 5 beds, plus 1 for each employee
h.
Houses of worship
1 for each 3.5 seats in the sanctuary
i.
Dancehalls and assembly halls without fixed seats, exhibition halls, except church assembly rooms in conjunction with auditoriums
1 for each 3 persons of design occupancy load
j.
Family daycare and foster family homes
1 for every 5 guests, plus 1 for the resident owner or manager
k.
Funeral homes, mortuaries
1 for each 5 seats of the aggregate number of seats provided in all assembly rooms
l.
Furniture and appliance stores, household equipment
1 for each 800 square feet of sales floor area
m.
Community care residential facilities
1 for each 5 guests, plus 1 for the manager, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
n.
Hospitals
1 for each bed, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
o.
Hotels, motels
1 for each unit intended for separate occupancy, plus 1 for the resident owner or manager
p.
Institutions for the aged
1 for every 5 guests, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
q.
Manufacturing plants, bottling plants, processing plants, packaging plants, furniture repair
1 for each 500 square feet of floor area
r.
Medical and dental clinics and offices
1 for each 200 square feet of floor area
s.
Medical (or convalescent) hospitals
1 for each 5 beds, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
t.
Nursing homes
1 for every 5 guests, plus 1 for the resident manager, plus 1 for each employee on the shift with the maximum number of personnel
u.
Physical fitness facilities
Multi-program:
1 space for each 100 square feet of floor area
Single-program:
• aerobics:
1 space for each 50 square feet of floor area
• basketball; volleyball:
1 space for each 3 persons of occupancy
• lap pool:
2 spaces per lane plus 1 space for each 300 square feet of non-pool floor area
• weightlifting:
1 space for each 250 feet of floor area
Physical fitness facilities with more than 15,000 square feet of floor area shall provide an additional 10 percent of the total number of required parking spaces
v.
Physical therapy
1 space per 200 square feet of floor area. In addition, 1 space per 50 square feet of pool (water) area
If the resulting number of parking spots contains a fraction and that fraction is greater than half you must round up and add a full parking space.
x
If you are located downtown ⇣, you don’t need to provide parking, but you must pay ⇣ for it.
x
More information coming soon.
Downtown has shared parking with reduced requirements. So if you don’t have off street parking, you can pay into a shared fund that runs the City garages and lots.
x

No making whiskey in your basement.

There are a few rules » about working from home, and a few things you should know about taxes ».

Home Occupation Regulations description from the code



If the name of your business does not contain your last name you will need to apply to county for a Fictitious business name (FBN).

For example if your businees is called “Smith’s Tanning” a FBN is NOT needed, but

if it is called “Jamaica Me Tan” a FBN is needed.

More information coming soon.


To work from home you need a Zoning Clearance (aka your use permit) which costs $221.00 »  and a business license which costs $145.15 » a year plus $4 for each additional employee.

Why does it cost $221.00

Why does it cost $145.15

Once you have your use permit and any tennant improvements approved, you’ll need a business licence from the Finance department.

Getting a Business license a is breeze.

Business Licenses help the city categorize employers and keep track of its employment base. This is important information that guides city services. Your business License needs to be renewed each year.

It is more of a tax than a license.
